Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2010 11:22PM mamaof3bugs wrote: I have had my port since Feb. and although it still freaks me out from time to time, it really has just become a part of me for the time being.  I will tell you that I cannot imagine going through chemo without it!  I was really worried about being accessed the first time too, turns out that is the easiest part.  The saline and heparin they use to flush the port taste awful, yes you taste it, but you can counteract the taste by chewing gum or sucking on orange 'mints.'  Make sure that the day you are accessed that you ask for either EMLA cream or lidocain for numbing.  The EMLA cream is a prescription you can get from your doctor.  Good luck and be fabulous no matter how you feel :D  Angi
Posts.Title: My port freaks me out a little lisasinglem tougherthanithought

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2010 11:40PM mamaof3bugs wrote:
Posts.Title: This makes me feel terrible...anyone else? shockedat39 chrishat

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2010 06:56AM mamaof3bugs wrote: I don't think that pink hatred is based on your stage...I'm a II and I HATE this freaking month!!  Melinda your post was fabulous...you are beautiful!  Screw breast cancer and all this pink stuff that goes with it, my favorite response when someone asking for a donation or I see someone wearing some form of breast cancer parifinalia  is "you wear it, I live it."  That is usually enough to get to stop and think.  I think most of us feel that Pinktober is a waste of time and a mass marketing, money making machine.  Hears to being a jaded grumpy BC survivor! Cheers (with pink champagne of course!) Angi

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2010 10:03PM mamaof3bugs wrote: My rad onc told me not to use any lotion unless I began to peel.  I use Radia Gel 2-3 times a day as prescribed by my doctor.  I was told to drink plenty of water to keep my skin hydrated and if I had to I could use cetaphil (sp?).  They don't want me using any over the counter products unless I clear it with them first.  Before using anything ladies make sure to talk with your doctors so that you don't mess with your rads :D  I have made it through 11 of 33 treatments...like my optimistic daughter pointed out, I am 1/3 of the way done!! xoxo, Angi

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2010 11:30PM mamaof3bugs wrote: Hello ladies.  I need to apologize for starting this thread and then not posting at all...it's been a crazy couple of weeks.  Today I had my first radiation and I cried.  The treatment itself of course was no big deal, it was the fact that once I am done with these 35 treatments I am done.  No pills for me, I am a triple negative so this is it.  I feel like I have been fighting this disease for the past 9 months with such intensity, how in the heck am I supposed to just walk away and be okay with that?  Anyway to say the least it is bittersweet, on one hand I cannot wait to be done with this nightmare but on the other I worry that I haven't done enough.  I guess only time will tell.  xoxo, Angi
Posts.Title: October 2010 rads mamaof3bugs JFV

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2010 01:42AM mamaof3bugs wrote: I have updated the list in the original post...if I missed you or you would like your name removed please let me know.  As for the rads they have been going pretty well.  I have nine done, only 23 left to go :D  I have an infection in my radiated breast which I was told is fairly common.  No problems with my skin yet (using Radia Gel) but the swelling is wow!  My boob is about twice the size it normally is and I am a DD so watch out LOL.  I have to say the rads are easy it the drive into Seattle everyday (40 mins one way) that is killing me!!  It sounds like everyone is doing well, this is just another step ladies...we will survive!!  xoxo, Angi

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2011 06:05PM mamaof3bugs wrote: Triple negative it the painful one...it grows so fast that your body doesn't have a chance to 'calm' the nerve endings.  Mine hurt like crazy and it came out of nowhere.

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2011 06:03PM mamaof3bugs wrote: Mine hurt like crazy!  Please don't wait any longer, go see your doctor.  Keep in mind most breast issues turn out to be b9 but you won't know until you get checked.  Angi
Posts.Title: Please help, did your lump hurt? Betterwannabe mtks

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2011 10:30PM mamaof3bugs wrote: At my first rads appointment they made my 'mold' that I laid in for the 36 treatments, placed my tattoos, and did a bunch of technical stuff I didn't understand.  That being said, I don't think anyone else would have understood it either :D  I meet my rads team and they explained to me what would happen for the next few weeks.  I went by myself and I am glad I did because like you I didn't want to make anyone wait and that is exactly what they would have been doing.  Good luck, the rads go quickly!! xoxo, Angi
Posts.Title: 1st Radiation Appointment - help! shoema shoema

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2010 07:08AM mamaof3bugs wrote: The claritin helps to combat the side effects of the nuelasta.  It helps with the achy joints caused by the shot.  Good luck with chemo, you can do it...I promise :D  Angi

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2010 11:41PM mamaof3bugs wrote: For those of you that had the oopherectomy did you have to stay over night in the hospital or was it a day surgery?  I will have mine at the end of the month and the surgery will be "blind" or completely vaginal, no exterior incisions due to a prior tummy tuck.  I have been trying to figure out if I will be overnighting at the hospital.  Thanks Ladies!!  Angi

Posts.Title: October 2010 rads mamaof3bugs JFV

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2010 12:16AM mamaof3bugs wrote: QCA tomorrow I will have #14!!  I cannot believe how quickly they are going...I saw my RO today.  My boob is still swelled but he isn't concerned and my skin is holding up fabulously!  I am a little more tired this week than last but NOTHING like chemo weeks!  AICa I see my Dr. every Thursday right after my zap.  Hope all is well with everyone!!  Angi
Posts.Title: October 2010 rads mamaof3bugs JFV

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2010 10:27PM mamaof3bugs wrote: I had #15 today and I think it is starting to get to me :(  I am exhausted and nauseated...really nausea??  I thought I left that behind with the chemo!  I am having shooting pain in my very swollen boob.  I spoke with my RO today and said that all my SEs are withing the normal range.  He gave me a script for some pain meds and wants me to stay on ibuprophen round the clock.  On a good note my skin is still doing fabulous, just a little pink.  By the end of the week I will be over half way done!!  Anyone else having nausea??  Keeping all of you in my prayers!!  Angi

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2012 02:50AM mamaof3bugs wrote: I go to Seattle Cancer Care Alliance and it is fabulous!
Posts.Title: move to seattle area rengeko petjunkie

Posts.Content: mamaof3bugs wrote: I had my lumpectomy on Feb. 22, almost six months ago and just now I am starting to have shooting pain and over all discomfort.  I still have some swelling and the pain usually only happens once I have taken my bra off.  Anyone else experiencing this?  I am almost done with my chemo but my tumor markers were up last week (53)so of course I am jumping to the worst possible conclusion...the TN cancer is back :(  I know the chances are slim but that slim chance still scares the poop out of me!  I completed 4 rounds of DD AC and I have done 14/16 rounds of taxol.  I spoke with my onc and she said not to worry that markers can go up during chemo and that my neuropathy can make them jump as well.  So any input on post lumpectomy pain would be appreciated :D  Thank youl, Angi Angi~ Dx 1/22/2010, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 0/12 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: lumpectomy pain... mamaof3bugs KeepingtheFaith

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2011 02:10AM mamaof3bugs wrote: I am one year out from my lumpectomy and still have pain daily.  I have spoken to my onc and BS about it and apparently it is 'normal' because our nerve ending are coming back to life.
Posts.Title: Twinges and lumpectomy Thatgirl Rachel1

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2010 02:36AM mamaof3bugs wrote: When I was diagnosed I went to the oncologist here in my 'smallish' hometown.  I had a MUGA, PET and breast MRI.  I was scheduled to have a brain scan but canceled it because I ended up getting my port that day instead...after we found out that the cancer was localized I sought a second opinion at a large cancer center in Seattle.  Once meeting with the drs in at SCCA I decided to transfer care to there and started my chemo almost immediately.  After talking with my onc, she explained that I would not have had any scans had I started treatment there because I was a stage IIa.  Now that I am done with chemo and will be starting rads in a few weeks I won't be having any scans, just blood draws with TMs.  I think that with early stage BC the doctors are less likely to do scans.  I am also a TN so I understand your concern, I am hoping that life and anxiety get easier over time :D
Posts.Title: Stage II - No scans?? SunnyCoconut Tabatha00

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2010 07:26AM mamaof3bugs wrote: God Bless all of you wonderful teachers!!!  Thank you for all you do...

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2010 03:50PM mamaof3bugs wrote: Welcome to the BCO boards Ansy.  I am so sorry to hear of your reconstruction nightmare!  It sounds as though you have finally found a good PS and will hopefully get the results you are looking for.  I am amazed that you continued to fly throughout your chemo, as a former FA I can honestly say I would not even had attempted it.  :D  Are you a triple negative?  I read that after your radiation you were done with treatment...I am also a TN and today was my first day of rads.  I feel the same as you, once I am done with rads, what then?  I hope you continue to post here and find comfort and encouragement.
Posts.Title: My Long Journey so far ansy mamaof3bugs

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2011 04:39AM mamaof3bugs wrote:
Posts.Title: 28 yrs old with Breast Cancer Stage I jwaldher mdg

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2011 03:48AM mamaof3bugs wrote: Not to scare you but there is some miss information  in a post that I have to correct...Breast Cancer can and many times DOES hurt!!!  I had a triple negative tumor that appeared in a few months time (3.5cm) and hurt like hell!  It is a misconception that it cannot or does not hurt.  I am not saying that you have a malignant turmor I just didn't want you to make any decisions based on misinformation. Good luck, I will keep you in my prayers.  Take care, Angi
Posts.Title: Breast lump @ 27, strong family history Lavender250 del4

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 10:00PM mamaof3bugs wrote: It is more than likely due to the steroids given with the AC... Angi
Posts.Title: Just Received first Chemo Treatment Tommilyn Letlet

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2011 04:15AM mamaof3bugs wrote: PS I was 37 at diagnosis on Jan. 21, 2010
Posts.Title: Going through Chemo and need support Braveheart Braveheart

Posts.Content: May 13, 2011 11:31AM mamaof3bugs wrote: I sported the mullet for about 2 months before I had the courage to have it cut!  According to my hairdresser it grows almost twice as fast around the perimeter of your head.  I take biotin every night to help with the growth.  Good luck and have fun with the shorter length, I had very long hair before chemo too and I have always wanted to knwo what I would look like with it short and now is my chance :D  My hairdresser has shown me numerous ways to style it.  Angi
Posts.Title: Chemo Curl nbills511 elmcity69

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2010 10:14AM mamaof3bugs wrote: Jenn I had horrible vision problems with Taxol.  I was wearing my "reading" glasses constantly.  As for the migraines, I have those all the time too and continued to have them throughout my 12 treatments.  I would speak with your onc just to double check but I am pretty sure those are both common SEs of the drug.  Maybe ask for a migraine med.because with migraines comes vision problems as well.  Good luck!  Angi
Posts.Title: Weird eye and headache issue while on Taxol yellow78 Faith316

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2010 03:37AM mamaof3bugs wrote: I am on taxol 9/12 and had steroids the first 4 treatments and decided after that I did not want to have the steroids any more.  My onc explained to me that the only thing the steroids are for (after the first treatment) is swelling in the legs and feet.  I have had no swelling and am so incredibly happy that I no longer have to deal with the 'roid rage :D  It is a personal decision but it will not effect the actual treatment in anyway.  Angi
Posts.Title: Help! Friend's Onc said she doesn't need steroids during Taxol. cs34 Lilah

Posts.Content: May 13, 2011 03:41AM mamaof3bugs wrote:
Posts.Title: Chemo Curl nbills511 elmcity69

Posts.Content: mamaof3bugs wrote: I had a lumpectomy on Feb. 16, I had 12 nodes removed (they were funky and all in bundles and all negative).  I am curious about how long it took for your lymphedema to happen?  I am having swelling in my armpit but it doesn't seem to have moved down my arm yet, what are the chances it will?  With everything going on this was my last concern but now that I have a little down time I am starting to worry.  Thanks for the input ladies!!  Angi Angi~ Dx 1/22/2010, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 0/12 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Swelling in armpit mamaof3bugs pattyrn212

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2011 04:14AM mamaof3bugs wrote: Braveheart I am sorry that you are having such a difficult time right now.  I am a trip neg, I am one year out from diagnosis and I am doing fabulously!!  Like you in the beginning everyone I knew looked at me with those sad eyes, now things seem to be back to normal.  I agree with proud mom, start a caringbridge page, that way people can keep up to date on your treatments and you don't have to continually tell people about it.  You are not alone, there are a lot of us tn's on here that will happily answers questions or just lend an ear.  As for the chemo, I did 4 DD AC followed by 12 weekly taxol...I tolerated all of it fairly well but the taxol was easier for me.  For the sores in your mouth make up some 'magic' mouthwash...equal parts liquid benadryl and maylox, swish is around and spit, it will numb your mouth and make it easier to eat.  I found that startches were easiest for me to eat, mashed potatoes were my fav.  You will make it through this and you aren't dying anytime soon!  Come back and visit whenever you need to chat :D  Angi
Posts.Title: Going through Chemo and need support Braveheart Braveheart

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2010 04:00PM mamaof3bugs wrote:  NO! Breast cancer can hurt...it did for me!  I have triple negative BC and because it grows so fast your body doesn't have the chance to "buffer" the tumor so it hurts.  I was told by a mammo tech that I was "too young, did have a history and oh BTW breast cancer doesn't hurt"  It's a damn good thing I didn't listen to her!!  Please go see your doctor, that is the only way you will knw for sure what is going on.  Chances are you will be fine, I know it is scary but ignorance is not bliss when it comes to this disease.  Please, please, please go see you doctor.
Posts.Title: everyone keeps telling me cancer doesn't hurt. is that true? jbarna Halah

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2010 02:34AM mamaof3bugs wrote: I understand your frustration and I think it is a travesty that women are sent home if they are not ready but please don't come to a cancer board and bodly declare that "....and that folks is why there will never be a cure for cancer nor any concern for the cancer patient and any other such illness."  We are all here to heal and hope, and comments like yours are hurtful.  Yes your boyfriends mother was sent home with only one nights stay, I was sent home about seven hours ago after having my ovaries removed.  I would most certainly rather be home tonight safe in my home surrounded by people that love me than at a hospital.  I can say without a shadow of a doubt that if there was a cure to be found my oncologist would be first in line to give it to her patients.  This board is here for anyone to come, to vent, cry, seek comfort and share joys...and you will find many women that feel the way you do, your words are just very frustrating for a patient that is in the midst of treatment.  I am sorry to be harsh but I am so sick of hearing there will never be a cure...I chose to be a glass half full kinda girl.  Oh and I am a proud American.
Posts.Title: Aftercare,or any care TigerPuss CoolBreeze
